How I Built My Portfolio

{/* Changed to text-black */}

November 22, 2024

Building my personal portfolio was a key project for me, not only because it represents my work, but also because it allowed me to showcase my web development skills. In this post, I’ll walk you through how I built my portfolio from scratch, the technologies I used, the design choices I made, and some lessons I learned along the way. 1. Defining the Goal The first step in building my portfolio was to define its purpose. I wanted it to: Showcase my web development skills. Provide a space for my projects, blogs, and skills. Be easy to update as I work on new projects. Have a minimalist design that focuses on the content. 2. Planning the Structure Next, I planned out the basic structure of my portfolio. I decided to include the following sections: Home: A brief introduction, my name, and a short tagline. About: A section where I talk about myself and my journey as a developer. Projects: A showcase of the projects I’ve worked on, each with descriptions and images. Skills: A section highlighting my technical skills, tools, and technologies I am proficient in. Contact: A form for potential clients or employers to get in touch with me. Blog: A place for sharing my thoughts, tutorials, and experiences in the field of web development. 3. Choosing the Technologies For the front-end, I chose to use React to build the components of my portfolio. React is a great choice because: It allows me to build reusable components. It’s highly efficient for rendering dynamic content. I used Tailwind CSS for styling because: It’s a utility-first framework that makes it fast to build custom designs. It keeps the CSS codebase clean and easy to manage.
